Award.AwardTitle: Supporting Staff Developers in the Implementation of Professional Development Programs to Improve Mathematics Education for Students with Disabilities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Education Development Center is carrying out a research and development project related to a set of professional development materials previously developed with support from the National Science Foundation. The materials, Math for All (MFA), are for the professional development of teachers who teach elementary school students with disabilities. The current project has three distinct components. 1) Conduct a qualitative study on the way the facilitators use the professional development materials. 2) Based on that study develop resources for teacher leaders and other facilitators of professional development. These resources include a Facilitator Case Book, a model for facilitator institutes, and a model for continued on-line support for facilitators. 3) Conduct an experimental study, using a randomized controlled trial model, to determine the effectiveness of these resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
School districts across the country face a pressing need to increase access to significant mathematics content for students with disabilities. To help address this issue, two NSF-funded projects, Math for All (MFA, elementary grades) and Addressing Accessibility in Mathematics (AAM, middle grades), created intensive professional development (PD) programs to help both general and special educators improve mathematics instruction for students with disabilities. Prior research indicated that these programs, when implemented by the developers themselves, have a positive impact on teachers’ content knowledge and instructional practices. However, since widespread use of these programs relies on their implementation by facilitators other than the developers, it was important to understand how staff developers enact the programs in their districts. The Supporting Staff Developers project identified facilitation challenges and investigated how a variety of approaches, such as facilitator guides, training institutes, and online websites, can support facilitators’ effective implementation of these programs with teachers.

 

In the initial phase of the study, facilitator questionnaires and intensive observations of district-based facilitators were used to identify implementation challenges. Among the identified challenges were understanding the goals and the content of the PD, making facilitation decisions that were consistent with the PD goals, and conducting productive discussions of video and student work artifacts. These results then informed the development and revision of a number of supports. In a second phase of our research, we investigated the impact of these supports on facilitators’ enactment of the programs and the impact on teachers. Data collected included facilitator questionnaires and follow-up interviews, facilitators’ session logs, staff observation of selected PD sessions, teacher pre- and post-program surveys, and teacher pre- and post-program content knowledge assessments.

 

An intensive training institute for facilitators, paired with detailed facilitator support materials in print and ongoing online support, contributed to facilitators’ implementation of the MFA and AAM programs with fidelity. Facilitators were able to lead the PD such that it had a positive effect on participating teachers: Across sites and programs, we found significant increases in teachers’ reports of preparedness and comfort with addressing students’ strengths and needs, and with planning accessible math lessons. We also found a significant increase in the frequency with which teachers reported using accessible instructional practices, such as assessing students’ strengths and needs, adapting lessons to meet different students’ strengths and needs, and use of accessible instructional strategies. These findings demonstrate the feasibility of using the MFA and AAM programs in a variety of settings, and attest to the scalability of the programs, i.e., their success in producing teacher outcomes regardless of whether they are implemented by the authors of the programs or staff developers who were not involved in their development.

 

This project had a direct impact on a large number of staff developers and teachers participating in the PD and research. We provided training and support to 105 facilitators in 11 states across the U.S. These facilitators implemented the PD with over 1,000 teachers, enhancing their preparation to broaden the participation of students with disabilities in high-quality mathematics education.
